newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE white sugar easier but off lows in PM.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE white sugar easier but off lows in PM.

text.p: White sugar futures were easier but above their session's lows. Traders said business was routine with light premium buying against New York's March the only dominant feature.
The March/March premium saw deals at $79, said one.
The New York raws contracts were marginally higher on scale-down trade buying on March and May.
Apart from that, dealings were quiet in the absence of fresh news and lack of participation due to a week-long trade gathering in London.
The market generally brushed aside news that a hurricane has flattened or flooded large areas of Cuban sugar cane and the damage may affect the 1996/97 harvest.
"The market prices don't seem to reflect the damage in Cuba. Obviously people think the situation is not quite like what they say," said one trader.
"I don't think it has caused particular damage to the sugar cane," said another. "The only thing is it may make harvesting a bit difficult."
But the Cuban state media said some 1.4 million acres of cane were affected in the western and central areas of the country.
By 1547 GMT, the most active March contract stood $1.40 lower at $312.70 after trading to a low of $312.40 during the session. The front-month December lost 90 cents at $316.50.
Turnover totalled 1,073 lots, with the Dec/March switch trading at $3.80.
No news emerged on Libya's recent buying tender for 14,000 tonnes of 45 ICUMSA white sugar after it postponed the deadline for bids to Monday.
Paris sugar also ticked lower on nearby contracts with March easing $1.30 to $312.80.
